newsitem.title: UK: Microsoft enlivens U.S. shares in London.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft enlivens U.S. shares in London.

text.p: Shares in Micrsosoft Corp were the standout feature in London trading of U.S. stocks on Friday after the software giant posted better-than-expected earnings after the New York close on Thursday, dealers said.
Microsoft shares were trading up at $103-1/4 by 1015 GMT, up from $100 in after-hours trading and up $5-1/8 from their New York close, and dragging other technology stocks higher in their wake.
"Microsoft has certainly lit up the tech stocks," said on trader in London. "Apart from that, things are pretty quiet."
International Business Machines Corp was quoted up $1/2 at $137-5/8, Texas Instruments was up 1/2 at 85-1/4 and Digital Equipment Corp was up $1/2 at 27-3/4.

Microsoft posted a jump in earnings per share to $0.79, up from $0.44 a year before and well above the $0.64 analysts had pencilled in. It said revenues from platform products such as the Windows operating system rose 73 percent to $1.68 billion.
However dealers here pointed to the cautious tone of the company's statement, saying the market's knee-jerk reaction to the headline earnings figures may prove short-lived.
"The statement was a bit cautious so we will have to see if it lasts," he said.
In an interview, Microsoft chief financial officer Mike Brown said he expected fourth-quarter earnings to be similar to those in the third quarter, which he said had been "sizzling."
Brown said he expected growth to slow over the next five quarters but to rise after that.
Elsewhere, trading in U.S. stocks was mixed after Thursday's 21.27 point drop in the Dow, its first lower close for four sessions.

AT&T Corp, due to report first-quarter results on Monday April 21, was unchanged at $33-3/4 after British Telecommunications Plc and its U.S. partner MCI Communications confirmed Spain's Telefonica would join its Concert alliance at the expense of AT&T's Unisource.
Dealers said the announcement had been expected and had no immediate impact on AT&T shares.

The June futures contract on the S&P 500 index was trading up 2.40 points at 768.40, pointing to a firm start on the Dow, while T-bonds were little changed, with the benchmark 30-year issue down 1/32 at 94-16.

Brokerage UBS said in a research note on Friday the Dow -- which touched a three-month low of 6,356.7 on April 14 -- was "extremely oversold" and with pension funds pouring in by the April 15 deadline, "these two forces should join hands to produce a rally in (in the Dow) to the 6,800 area in the near term."
"Strong volume and breadth on this advance would indicate strong demand for equities at current levels, and the likelihood that the worst of the correction is over," UBS said.
But it added: "If the market cannot generate such demand, the odds of another downleg are high."
